result.markdown:
--- title: "Indoor Triathlon Provincial Championship Series - Race 3" date: "2025-04-12" author: "Adrian Joseph" image: "https://storage.googleapis.com/blogs_josa/sport/2025-02-22_INDOOR_TRIATHLON_SERIES_RACE_1/img/00.png" categories: [race report, triathlon, indoor] format: html lightbox: match: auto effect: fade desc-position: right loop: false --- ![](https://storage.googleapis.com/blogs_josa/sport_small/2025-02-22_INDOOR_TRIATHLON_SERIES_RACE_1/img/00.png) # Overview This was the third race in the Ontario Indoor Triathlon Championship series. I talked about the format in general in [this page](../2025-02-22_INDOOR_TRIATHLON_PROVINCIAL_CHAMPIONSHIP_-_RACE_1/index.qmd). In summary, in this series you get points for how far you swim, bike, and run in 15 minutes. The further you go, the more points you get. The series is made by 4 races, but only the top 3 results count towards the final total. Whoever gets more points at then end of the series wins the championship and get the trophy. Age Grouper can still hope to win bragging rights -and a downloadable certificate- if they place at the top of their 10 years group. Going into this event I had 2 objective: * Maintain the age group leadership. * Do better (or at least not worse) that the previous event. I had no aspiration for the overall title because there is no way that at 40+ years of age I can compete with some 20years old in this type of events. So, how did it go? ## Races comparison I'll do some more in depth analysis at the end of the series. For now, here is the overall official record. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |Race [#] | Swim [laps]| Bike [km]| Run [km]| |:--------|-----------:|---------:|--------:| |Race 1 | 825| 9.0| 3.0| |Race 3 | 775| 10.6| 3.3| ::: ::: The swim was disappointing. I felt like I was doing a good job. I swam the first few minutes trailing behind the other guy in my lane -which I think is the guy who finished second in the age group-, but then I passed him and kept the lead. Clearly I have been managing my energy too conservatively. On the bike I felt good. Again I tried to not get too tired out, and this time I actually cycled for the whole 15min, I did not start late. I do not recall exactly for how long I cycled in the first race, but probably around 13min. That would be an average speed of 41.5km/h. This time I did 10.6Km and I stopped at around 14:45, since I knew I could not do 400 more meters in 15seconds and get more points. That would be 43.1km/h. So about 1.5km/h faster. The run was my highlight of the day. I started easy. 3 guys went off immediately, but they stayed only about 20m ahead. I slowly caught them all. In the final minutes two of the three -two guys in their early twenties-, picked up the pace again and I just could not stay with them, but I did stay ahead of my rival for the Age Group first place. In the end I covered 300m more than in the previous race, which does not sound like much, but that is the difference between 5min/km and 4:30min/km. So still not where I want to be, but getting there. ## Ranking ### Race ranking In this race I finished 7$^{th}$ overall and 2$^{nd}$ in the Age Group. The guy that finished first was incredible: 21 swim laps (1050m), 10.5Km on the bike, and 18.5 run laps (3.7Km). Just no way I can keep up with him, especially in the water. This is the whole ranking for my age group. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Name Swim score Bike score Run score Final score Overall ranking Age Grooup ranking
PAUL BREGIN 420 525 463 1408 2 1
ADRIAN JOSEPH 310 530 413 1253 7 2
PAUL BOSHYK 310 500 400 1210 10 3
NICK KOVACS 300 500 400 1200 12 4
SEAN TEVLIN 290 500 400 1190 13 5
CHRIS SWEETING 300 445 325 1070 23 6
STEVE YOUNG 320 425 325 1070 24 7
CHRISTOPHER LASZLO 260 465 288 1013 32 8
````` ::: ::: ### Series ranking #### Overall ranking The good news for me is that Paul Bregin did not do race 1, so as long as I complete the next race at roughly the same level as this, he cannot catch me in the overall ranking. With that said, here is the overall ranking (male only). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Name Points n_races
PAUL SHORTIS 2829 2
ADRIAN JOSEPH 2409 2
LUCIEN PERON 2359 2
NICK KOVACS 2351 2
KEITH BROWN 2249 2
PAUL DUHAMEL 2149 2
ROBERT CAMPBELL 2086 2
CHRISTOPHER LASZLO 2077 2
STEVE YOUNG 2071 2
JULIAN KENNEY 1706 2
````` ::: ::: This table tells me a few things: * If Paul Shortis does not show up at the next race, I have a shot at the championship. Unlikely, but possible. Otherwise, no way I can close that gap of 395 points. * For the Age Group championship, it is tight. I have a 53 points lead, and it does not take much to rack up more than 53 points: Swim 25m more, bike 500m more, run 200m more, and you have collected 60 extra points. What gives me hope is that until now I always managed to outperform Nick in every sport -well, except the bike on the first race obviously-. But you've never won until you crossed the finish line first! I still need to show up and work for it. #### Gender ranking ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Name Points n_races
ADRIAN JOSEPH 2409 2
NICK KOVACS 2351 2
CHRISTOPHER LASZLO 2077 2
STEVE YOUNG 2071 2
PAUL BREGIN 1409 1
````` ::: ::: I do have some competition to keep an eye on. While I managed to outrace Nick every time we met, there is not a very big difference. A bad swim, a run injury, or another mistake on the bike and I can lose my lead to him. ## Waiting for race 4 Race 4 is coming soon: May 4$^{th}$. It is going to be an interesting one. All out to protect the Age Group lead! ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
